title: Pandas: Handling Missing Values
story: Missing data is common in real-world datasets. Learn to detect, count, and handle NaN values effectively.
instructions: Count the number of missing values in each column and print as a Series. The data has NaN in 'age' and 'score' columns.
starterCode:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = {
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'age': [25, np.nan, 30],
    'score': [85, 90, np.nan]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Count missing values per column
missing_count = df.isnull().sum()
print(missing_count)
solutionHidden:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = {
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'age': [25, np.nan, 30],
    'score': [85, 90, np.nan]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
missing_count = df.isnull().sum()
print(missing_count)

tests.description: Should count 0 for name, 1 for age, 1 for score

hints.text: Use df.isnull().sum() to count missing values per column.
isnull() creates boolean mask, sum() counts True values (missing data).
